Award.AwardTitle: Effect of polarization and charge on biological halogen bonds
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division, Drs. Pui S. Ho and Anthony K. Rappe, from Colorado State University, will characterize the geometry-energy relationships of, and derive from these relationships methods to model halogen bonds (X-bonds) accurately in biological systems. X-bonds are important non-covalent interactions in defining the specificity of many inhibitors to their protein targets. The hypothesis is that X-bonds are underutilized in inhibitor design, because of our incomplete understanding for how their geometries define their energies. The long-term goal of the research is to develop a set of potential energy functions to describe X-bonds, starting with extensive characterization of the geometry-energy relationships for the interactions in biological molecules. To accomplish these goals, the researchers will compare the effects of polarization of the halogen X-bond donor and the charge of the X-bond acceptor on the structure and energies of X-bonds in DNA junctions in T4 lysozyme. They will also study how these physicochemical effects contribute to ligand binding using a set of lysozyme constructs with artificial pockets engineered at various sites in the protein. Finally, they will develop quantum chemical methods to model the experimental structure-energy relationships. The experimental and quantum mechanical results will eventually be integrated to develop new potential energy functions for biological X-bonds that can be incorporated into molecular mechanics force fields that are used in biomolecular modeling.

The outcomes of this research project are likely to impact the computer-aided design of new classes of drugs. Efforts will also be made to integrate research with science education, by using scientific problems derived from the research component to guide class projects related to the basic principles taught in a Physical Biochemistry course. Finally, this project, which integrates experimental and theoretical methods to characterize unique molecular interactions, is expected to continue to provide a diverse group of postdoctoral trainees, graduate and undergraduate students (including women and students of diverse backgrounds) with broad training in the areas of structural biology and biological chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was funded to study halogen bonds, a molecular interaction that we had discovered as being important in biology. The interaction has been shown to be involved in, for example, the binding of inhibitors to proteins and enzymes, and in driving DNAs to adopt new structures. By engineering halogenated bases into a unique four-stranded DNA molecule (the Holliday junction), we were able for the first time to accurately measure the energies of halogen bonds in a biological molecule, showing that this interaction is as strong or stronger than the better known and more ubiquitous hydrogen bond. In addition, we have started to engineer halogen bonds into polypeptides to affect the thermal stability of proteins. From these experimental results, we have derived a novel set of computational models to accurately predict the strength of the interactions.

The project has broad impacts in providing tools to help design new halogenated molecules as more potent inhibitors and drugs, and to design new molecular materials based on biomolecular structures. We have been able to show that the stability of proteins can be changed by engineering halogen bonds at specific amino acid positions (patent filed).  The computational tools that we have developed are being incorporated into standard computer programs to help simulate the structure and stability of proteins and their bound inhibitors (patent filed). The funded project resulted in ten publications, with 2 recognized by Thompson-Reuters Web of Science as "Highly Cited Papers" (among the top 1% in citations) and 3 featured on the covers of their respective journals; and resulted in 2 patents filed. The studies were highlighted in 4 published commentaries (August 2014 in Nature Chemistry; February, 2013 in Protein Science; and August, 2012 in Chemical and Engineering News) and one radio interview on Science Studio (KTEP), March 1, 2015, (url: http://ktep.org/post/science-studio-structural-biology).

The grant supported the training of 6 PhD and 1 MS graduate students, along with 2 undergraduate and one high school student. In addition, a review article on halogen bonds written by the PI was published in The F&M Scientist, a magazine targeted towards undergraduates, and friends and alumni of Franklin and Marshall College, a nationally ranked selective liberal arts college. Finally, we have extended our expertise to hands-on K-12 outreach programs that teach students about how molecular structures are determined and why they are important in understanding their functions in biology.
